column6: Which CNCF Project(s) are you maintaining?
column37: What is your feeling with respect to your overall experience with CNCF, where 5 is completely met expectations and 1 - did not meet expectations?

column49: Efficiency: Did you feel that the CNCF team responded quickly to your requests? Where 5 is work was completed on time or ahead of schedule and 1 is delayed?

column95: I know the CNCF doesn't sponsor feature work, but that would be the greatest help. I've mentored a lot of people who would have made Prometheus more diverse, but they typically never stay long enough to become relevant contributors because they just do it in their free time and don't get paid. Temporary scholarships could maybe be a good compromise and maybe would enable them to find a job where they get paid for Prometheus maintenance.

column97: CNCF could encourage the projects to leverage other members if needed.

Getting a ton of help from Luc on website automation, but not on actual doc writing. Still need help with doc writing!    Getting some use out of the community cluster, but what we really want is a cross-environment testbed (e.g. we've been finding AKS-specific issues). This would dramatically increase the quality of the project.    Really want a paid Slack for Linkerd. Our whole community is there and we lose history really rapidly. It's a bummer.    Finally, while it's nice to get RTs, there is so much press and marketing from the CNCF around Istio (a competitive, non-CNCF project), from conferences to sponsorships to newsletters, that it can be pretty discouraging. You should have our back on this.

column64: I was vaguely aware this was possible, and I raised it a few times, but nothing concrete has come out of it yet.
column70: I feel the CNCF should play a larger roll in making testing easier. Not sure how this technically should look, but if you look at projects like MetalLB and CoreDNS we have a clear need for (scale) testing and an easy way to slot in our dev code in a running k8s cluster. I.e. it would work if travis would support a k8s runtime where you can specify where your code is being slotted in and then testing.

column76: We have not had any security audits performed, I was not aware of the security services offered by the CNCF.

column88: Kubecons are amazing and the opportunities we get to connect with the community on the maintainer track is great, and the conference presence of the Rook logo/name is great too.  We have also had great visibility on twitter from the CNCF account.
column94: I spoke about this in a New Stack podcast interview alongside Ihor.  2 things I think the CNCF provides most notably: 1) Technical vetting, getting accepted to the CNCF and especially at the Incubation level is a great approval of the project for the broader community to feel safe adopting it.  It's a respected stamp of approval.  2) Reach - the amount of visibility we get to the broader ecosystem by being a CNCF project is great.  Most people at Kubecons have heard of Rook now, so that marketing reach is really impressive and helpful.
column95: It may be cool to do something in the same vein that Google Summer of Code does.  Perhaps set up a few stipends for people that want to contribute to CNCF projects but don't have the resources.  This could encourage and incentive many new contributors to join the CNCF project communities.  I think this could be done at any time of the year, as opposed to run as a specific time period for everyone like GSoC does it.  Getting more diverse folks from all around the world involved in the CNCF projects would be awesome!
column96: What I'm noticing that I've personally missed is the reach and awareness of all the services that are offered by the CNCF.  Security audits, bots/automation, etc. I didn't even know were available.  I take responsibility for that of course too, but there could be a more vocal and visible campaign from the CNCF to make these services well known by the projects.  I think maintainers don't necessarily even know what their project needs.  Perhaps the CNCF can have full project reviews and explicitly state/offer what services the project needs or should take advantage of.  Looks like there are some great services and we as a maintainer team have not been taking advantage of them.
column97: I think my biggest point is in the last question about visibility of the CNCF services.  I'd love a CNCF expert to do a review of the Rook project and say hey we have service x, y, and z that would really benefit you all.  I take responsibility that we haven't taken the initiative ourselves, but having an expert from the CNCF that knows all the services and how they can be utilized reaching out to all the projects could make these services more available and utilized as a whole.  The visibility and technical approval that the CNCF has given us has been incredible, I am very pleased and grateful for that.  Keep up the great work!

column88: I am not involved enough in PromCon to comment on that, regarding velocity reports I wish they were better scoped to our project and ecosystem, I think they're generally great, but little helpful with the current information (this is probably primarily a lack of us not specifying detail, but that would mean a large part of this would be done by the team not as a service by the CNCF).
column94: The CNCF feels less and less like it is about engineering excellence, than it was perceived to be when it was created and Prometheus joined. From a marketing perspective it's great for a project to do so, but any new project that has joined recently I highly doubt that it actually went through a proper technical review. My feeling is that the standard for software has lowered over the years. So there are positives as projects get lots of attention due to being in the CNCF but by now it feels a lot like politics and power-play.
column95: I think for the Prometheus team the biggest problem is lack of resources to on-board people, which also has an effect on the diversity on the team, as we can't invest in mentoring people to become part of the team. I think this is somewhat unrealistic but "sponsored mentorships" maybe for freelancers of the team could be an option.
